evidence_span: anodizing solution used to improve contrast between intermetallic compounds in zirconium and zirconium alloys is as follows: $6 0 \mathrm { m l }$ absolute ethanol, $3 5 ~ \mathrm { m l }$ water, ${ 2 0 } \ \mathrm { m l }$ glycerine, $\mathbf { \ell } _ { \mathbf { i 0 \ m l } }$ lactic acid (85 percent), EY $5 \mathrm { m l }$ phosphoric acid (85 percent), and ${ \boldsymbol { 2 } } \mathbf { g }$ citric acid

evidence_span: typical power supply should have a $2 0 0 \ \mathbf { V }$ maximum capacity with a current rating of approximately l A. (Occasionally, voltages up to 300 are useful)

evidence_span: When working with as much as 50 to 200 V dc

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: For routine metallographic observation of zirconium alloys, $1 1 5 \ \mathbf { V }$ produces the most contrast between the greatest number of compounds and phases.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: At $1 1 5 \mathrm { \bf ~ V }$ , silicides and phosphides are a deep gold color as compared to a yellow color for carbides.

evidence_span: The materials described in this paper are of several types. Some are commercial alloys, such as Zircaloy-2 and Zircaloy-4 which have been well characterized in the literature.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: This material has a hardness of $3 3 4 \mathrm { ~ H B }$ , and is practically nonfabricable.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: Zircaloy-4 with elevated phosphorus content, approximately 70 ppm, results in long, lenticular zirconium-phosphide particles in the as-cast condition.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: The angularity and sharpness of these intermetallic compounds is altered little by heat treating as high as $2 2 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { F }$ $( 1 2 0 4 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C } )$ for $2 4 \ \mathrm { h }$

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: Figure 5 shows the result of an as-cast button containing 116-ppm phosphorus as well as 140-ppm silicon.

evidence_span: The microstructure in Fig. 7 shows more ZrC, this time in Zircaloy-2 in an as-cast 14-in.-diameter ingot. The carbon level in this case is approximately 400 ppm

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: The lower voltage anodized film, 28 V, shows the carbides as a solid, smooth intermetallic compound.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk3
evidence_span: This same sample, with no new preparation, reanodized at a higher voltage (1 15 V), shows the anodized film breaking down and resulting in a very mottled appearing carbide.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk4
evidence_span: The photomicrograph shown in Fig. 8 is a typical example of flowed metal from improper polishing.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk4
evidence_span: The effective use of heat tinting relies on variations in the oxidation rate of different areas of the sample. For constant oxidation parameters, the oxide film thickness depends on the oxidation rate of the substrate.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk4
evidence_span: To form the oxide layer, place the sample in a small oven set at approximately 400°C.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk4
evidence_span: The sample should remain in the oven until a light reddish-brown oxide is formed. This is in the range of 2 to 10 min for a furnace temperature of 400°C.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk4
evidence_span: For determining oxidation time, it is best to experiment with a sample of Zircaloy-4 in an as-cast condition.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk4
evidence_span: For an evaluation of metallographic techniques, it is best to prepare a sample of homogeneous, alpha-recrystallized Zircaloy.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk4
evidence_span: Figure 9 shows a single crystal sphere of unalloyed zirconium which has been oxidized in air.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk4
evidence_span: For polycrystalline material, the polished surface of each grain has a specific orientation and therefore a different oxidation rate and different color. This is shown in Fig. 10.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk4
evidence_span: Alloy microsegregation typical of as-cast Zircaloy-4 is shown in Fig. 11. Many of the individual grains in Fig. 11 have tin variations from edge to center of 0.1 to 0.4 percent.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk4
evidence_span: Tin segregation in a sample of Zircaloy-4 with an alpha recrystallized structure is shown in Fig. 12.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: The structure in Fig. 13 is a longitudinal micro similar to the one in Fig. 12. The dominant features are the elongated tin-rich stringers in an equiaxed alpha-structure. This type of structure will not have good corrosion resistance to elevated-temperature steam.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: The tin-rich areas will oxidize faster than the matrix and appear as gray striations on the corrosion film.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: the weight gain should be normal for a 14-day, ${ 7 5 0 ^ { \circ } } \mathbf { F }$ $( 4 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C } )$ , 1500-psi steam test

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: small amounts of contamination picked up during the fabrication of welded zirconium alloy components has significantly impaired the high temperature water corrosion properties of the final product

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: Among these contaminants, nitrogen and tungsten have proved to be the most serious and frequent

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: The microstructures of nitrogen-rich areas in production components have been examined using anodizing techniques (Fig. 14)

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: these structures have been simulated (Fig. 15) in button melted homogeneous Zircaloy/nitrogen mixtures

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: The effect of heat treatment upon the corrosion properties and upon the microstructure has been studied

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: a secondary precipitate within the Widmanstätten needles is thought to explain changes in corrosion properties not previously understood

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: Figures 14 through 17 were produced after anodizing at $1 5 0 \mathrm { V }$ in a phosphoric acid solution

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: Anodizing on a macroscopic scale to evaluate production components affected by nitrogen has proved less sensitive than corrosion testing

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: Tungsten/nitrogen contamination of welded components has been illustrated in a similar manner (Fig. 18)

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: Foreign particles in components manufactured from Zircaloy powder have been revealed by heat tinting (Fig. 19)

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: for the beryllium rich type of inclusions experienced, heat tinting has proved to be more sensitive than the anodizing technique

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: The general background internal friction variation with temperature is considered to be due to the oscillations of the dislocation segments in metal crystals

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: When these segments are strongly pinned by impurities or precipitates, then the background level reduces considerably

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: Under certain experimental conditions, zirconium hydride precipitates along the dislocations so as to pin the dislocation segments firmly

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: For a given composition of $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } { \mathbf { - } } \mathbf { H }$ alloy, the maximum temperature at which there is a measurable decrease in internal friction, due to precipitation, indicates the maximum solubility at that temperature
